newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss govt says new bond to bring life to long end.
newsitem.headline: Swiss govt says new bond to bring life to long end.

text.p: The Swiss Federal government on Tuesday launched a 20-year bond, a move aimed a creating more liquidity in the long end which will also benefit the swap market, said Peter Thomann, head of the Swiss Treasury.
"Basically we have the intention of keeping the maturity spectrum as broad as possible," he said in a telephone interview with Reuters.
"We are also interested in having the swap market extend beyond 10 years. We are helping a bit with that," he said.
Thomann said the Swiss swap market for longer maturities is gradually being built up in the area beyond 10 years.
Terms for the latest offering will be set on Thursday. The new bond has a 4-1/4 percent coupon, with the allocation limited to a maximum one billion Swiss francs.
It is the longest maturity to be launched by the Swiss government since two 25-year bonds were set in 1986 and 1987.
Those offerings are relatively illiquid.
One Swiss bond trader believed the government had set unattractive terms on its new bond to keep demand down.
"There is no real interest. The government doesn't need much money. I don't expect much demand for the issue," he said.
But Thomann said investors may be drawn by higher yields offered by longer maturities. The yield on the new bond was quoted in the grey market at 4.23 percent.
By contrast, the benchmark June 4-1/2 percent 2007 10-year bond yields currently just a bit more than 3.50 percent.
Based on current relatively low Swiss interest rates, "I don't expect that we will be sorry in future that we borrowed in a longer maturity," Thomann said.
The offering should also draw long-term investors, he said.
"For investors (the new bond) is also not unattractive, if one believes that interest rates in 1997, 1998 and possibly 1999 will only rise slightly," he said.
The Swiss Federal Treasury's previous auction in March comprised a three-year, and a 17-year tranche.
Thomann noted the offerings drew equal demand.
He said those who bought the 17-year tranche "have no need to complain. They paid 98.50," he said. The outstanding 17-year bond was quoted on Tuesday at 101.00/101.50.
Thomann said the Treasury's relatively low need for liquidity gave it some leeway to experiment.

Swiss government borrowing so far this year has totalled roughly 2.24 billion francs on a gross basis, not including redemptions. In addition, there was a further 350 million taken up for the Treasury's own coffers.
According to plan, the Treasury would need to average 550 million francs per bond auction for the remainder of 1997.
But the Treasury was flexible, Thomann said, adding late last year, for example, it was one billion francs below plan.
